titleStmt.title: A crucial review on polycyclic aromatic Hydrocarbons -Environmental occurrence and strategies for microbial degradation

affiliation.orgName: Department of Animal Health and Management

analytic.title: A crucial review on polycyclic aromatic Hydrocarbons -Environmental occurrence and strategies for microbial degradation

biblStruct.note: Received 2 February 2021; Received in revised form 31 March 2021; Accepted 12 April 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Over the last century, contamination of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) has risen tremendously due to the intensified industrial activities like petrochemical, pharmaceutical, insecticides and fertilizers applications. PAHs are a group of organic pollutants with adverse effects on both humans and the environment. These PAHs are widely distributed in various ecosystems including air, soil, marine water and sediments. Degradation of PAHs generally occurs through processes like photolysis, adsorption, volatilization, chemical degradation and microbial degradation. Microbial degradation of PAHs is done by the utilization of diverse microorganisms like algae, bacteria, fungi which are readily compatible with biodegrading/bio transforming PAHs into H 2 O, CO 2 under aerobic, or CH 4 under anaerobic environment. The rate of PAHs degradation using microbes is mainly governed by various cultivation conditions like temperature, pH, nutrients availability, microbial population, chemical nature of PAHs, oxygen and degree of acclimation. Several microbial species including Selenastrum capricornutum, Ralstonia basilensis, Acinetobacter haemolyticus, Pseudomonas migulae, Sphingomonas yanoikuyae and Chlorella sorokiniana are known to degrade PAHs via biosorption and enzyme-mediated degradation. Numerous bacterial mediated PAHs degradation methods are studied globally. Among them, PAHs degradation by bacterial species like Pseudomonas fluorescence, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Rhodococcus spp., Paenibacillus spp., Mycobacterium spp., and Haemophilus spp., by various degradation modes like biosurfactant, bioaugmentation, biostimulation and biofilms mediated are also investigated. In contrarily, PAHs degradation by fungal species such as Pleurotus ostreatus, Polyporus sulphureus, Fusarium oxysporum occurs using the activity of its ligninolytic enzymes such as lignin peroxidase, laccase, and manganese peroxidase. The present review highlighted on the PAHs degradation activity by the algal, fungal, bacterial species and also focused on their mode of degradation.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Human civilization and development has led to the instigation of several contaminants into the environment, among which petroleum hydrocarbons are extensively dumped into various spheres. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are made of two or more fused benzene rings with different structural configurations generated by incomplete combustion of both natural (forest fires, volcanic eruptions) and human anthropogenic activities (fossil fuels, petroleum refining, coal gasification, and waste incineration). PAHs are mainly a fraction of petroleum hydrocarbons and it is the foremost energy source in contemporary society (Ravindra et al., 2008). The higher number of PAHs released form petroleum resources (94%) are primarily used in different sectors such as road transport, industrial, commercial and residential usages. Most of the pollution is contributed by urban areas such as the fossil fuel industry, motor vehicles, electricity generation, etc. Moreover, existing oil demand is also constantly raised due to the population growth and explicit usages (Ball and Truskewycz, 2013).

Currently, more than 100 diverse PAHs, both individual and mixed have been reported. The high-molecular-weight (HMW) PAHs comprise four or more aromatic rings where low-molecular-weight (LMW) PAHs contain three or fewer aromatic rings. Few examples of PAHs are acenaphthene, anthracene, benzo [a] [a,h]anthracene, indeno [1,2,3-c,d]pyrene,phenanthrene, pyrene (Kuppusamy et al., 2017). The microbial (Algae, fungi and bacteria) mediated PAHs degradation is biotransformation of compounds into less complex metabolites like H 2 O, CO 2 (aerobic) or CH 4 (anaerobic). The PAHs degradation by using algae, fungi and bacteria is extensively studied because of their quick environment adaptation. The PAHs degradation rate varies depends on many factors such as microbial population, chemical structure, accessibility of nutrients, degree of acclimation, oxygen, pH and temperature. The main objective of this review is to summarize microbial (Algae, bacteria, fungi) mediated PAHs degradation and their different strategies are thoroughly discussed.

div.head: Occurrence and transport of PAHs
div.p: Various types of PAHs are discharged into the environment by both natural (forest fires, volcanic eruptions) and anthropogenic activities (fossil fuels, petroleum refining, coal gasification, and waste incineration). United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA) has listed 16 PAHs as priority pollutants which are spotlighted globally ( Table 1).

The anthropogenic activities release PAHs into diverse environments like aquatic environments, deposition to surface water, soils, sediments and air. According to Zhang et al., (2009) every year, approximately 520,000 metric tons (globally) of PAHs are released into ecosystems from various sources like biofuels (56.9%), wildfires (17%) and consumer products (6.9%). Globally three countries (China -22%, India-17% and the United States -6.5%) contribute nearly 45.5% of total PAHs dumped in the atmosphere every year. Besides, every year about 209, 000 tons of PAHs are released into aquatic environments (Eisler, 2000;Aboal et al., 2020;Wang et al., 2021). Over the last decades, the marine ecosystem has been contaminated by PAHs discharges from domestic, industrial wastewater, urban runoff and oil derivation that are extensively studied worldwide (Elias et al., 2007). The entry of PAHs into the diverse environment with their respective sources of entry has been depicted in Fig. 1.

div.head: PAHs in marine sediments
div.p: According to Duran and Cravo-Laureau (2016), some of the worst oil spill accidents occurs internationally are primarily due to the introduction of enormous PAHs into the marine environments. The first Gulf War in Kuwait, Erikain France, Prestigein Spain, Exxon Valdez in Alaska and the recent accident of the Deepwater Horizon in the Gulf of Mexico are some of the best examples of PAHs dumped into the marine environment. These type of accidents account for less than 10% of PAHs contamination in the marine environment, but oil seepage holds up to 47% of hydrocarbon contamination in the marine environments (Duran and Cravo-Laureau, 2016).

The coastlines account for several ecosystems such as mangroves, estuaries, coral reefs, bays, lagoons and salt marshes that are sensitive to the pollutants. But in recent years, several reports identified PAHs contamination in the ecosystems such as salt marshes (Chronopoulou et al., 2013), coral reefs (Bayen, 2012;Guigue et al., 2015) and even in the arctic region (Jörundsdóttir et al., 2014). The properties such as low solubility in water, hydrophobicity, the high vapor pressure of PAHs are the main factors allowing it to settle in marine sediment easily; these are sensitive indicators of natural pollutants (Koh et al., 2004), which settle permanently and are a considered a higher threat to aquatic N. Premnath et al. environments. PAHs compounds possess various carcinogenic and mutagenic properties which are resulted by accumulation with subsequent internal organ damage in fish (development of tumours, ovipositional deterrence and uncontrolled gonadal development) (Barbour et al., 2008). Acceding to Baumard et al., (1998) (Abdollahi et al., 2013). The contamination of marine sediments by PAHs has been depicted in Fig. 2. The marine ecosystem gets primarily contaminated with the PAHs released from industrial areas. Some important polluted sites are coal and biomass combustion deposits in estuaries of the Linhong River (Zhang et al., 2013), Pearl River Delta in China (Wang et al., 2007), San Francisco Estuary in the USA (Oros and Ross, 2004), Yangtze River (Guo et al., 2007) in China, Mersey Estuary in the UK (Vane et al., 2007) and petroleum combustion deposits in Malaysian estuaries (Keshavarzifard et al., 2015). Across southwestern and northern Norway, 22 types of PAHs were detected in both freshwater and marine sediment between the periods of 1950-2002 and 1800 to 2004, respectively (Eide et al., 2011). Similarly, 22 different PAHs were detected in lake sediment range from 217 to 7045 ng/g dry wt. Highly contaminated sites of PAHs throughout the world was observed in the harbours of Yangshan Port in China (Li et al., 2015), Olbia harbour in Italy (De Luca et al., 2005) and
Khomeini Port in Iran (Abdollahi et al., 2013).

div.head: PAHs in air
div.p: Studies of PAHs pollution in the air have gained greater attention and thereby creates a severe impact on the environment. Accumulation of PAHs in the atmosphere has mostly resulted in the deposition of PAHs in soil. The ambience of PAHs in the air is readily based on the PAHs molecular weight, particulate stage (sorbed to aerosols) and gas phase (Gao et al., 2015;Dat and Chang, 2017;Han et al., 2018). According to Bozlaker et al. (2008), instigation of PAHs in the air is vitally by the humanmade circumstances like fuels, feedstocks (release of fragments of PAHs) (Mi et al., 2000) and chemical combustion (pyrolysis of hydrocarbons). Σ-15-PAH (particulate + gas) concentrations were found to be available in both seasons, such as summer (7.3 and 44.8 ngm − 3 ) and winter (10.2-71.9 ngm − 3 ) in Turkey Aliaga industrial region. The concentration of PAHs varies from one place to another, which is higher in industrial, urban, or residential areas but lower in remote or rural areas (Mi et al., 2000;Bozlaker et al., 2008). Liu et al. (2014a) indicated that concentrations of atmospheric PAHs in two urban sites (Chicago and Cleveland near Great Lakes) are 20 times higher compared to the other sites. For instance, PAHs concentration is higher in urban (5 times) and industrial areas (10 times) than the rural areas while are probably increased during the period of sugarcane-burning (9.7 times higher) than the non-sugarcane burning periods (Cristale et al., 2012). The PAHs distribution in the air is classified into two types, such as stationary source and mobile source (Fig. 3). The examples of stationary sources are industrial production (power plant, asphalt plant, coking plant, boiler and waste incinerator), residential combustion (tobacco smoking, cooking and heating), organized or unorganized agricultural burning. Examples of the mobile sources are exhausts like shipping, railways, aircraft and motor vehicles activities (Zhang et al., 2020). The size of the PAHs particle is larger in mobile sources and smaller in stationary sources. HMW-PAHs are associated with smaller particles and LMW-PAHs are associated with larger particles (Zhang et al., 2020).

div.head: PAHs in food
div.p: The food cycle contaminated with PAHs is a major problem for human health. The different routes (known and unknown) of PAHs food contamination include soiling of foods, mainly fruits and vegetables. The agricultural lands nearby the industrial area are readily contaminated (even by traffic exhaust) results in air particulates deposited on the grain, vegetable seeds, waxy surface of vegetables and fruits. Employment of high temperature while bread processing could sometimes be contaminated by PAHs, which are thus considered a severe threat to human health (Orecchio and Papuzza, 2009;Ciecierska and Obiedziński, 2013). According to Nieva-Cano et al. (2001), about 7.38-18.0 μg/kg of PAHs was found in the toasted bread.

PAHs contaminated food products which are plant-based by different uptake are the other sources of PAHs exposure to humans.These are done in many ways like soil uptake, atmospheric exposure, autogenous biosynthesis, in which atmospheric exposure is the main way of PAHs contamination (Guillén et al., 1997). Mostly leafy vegetables are easily contaminated by PAHs due to the facilitation of larger, waxy, cuticle surface areas of leaves for easy PAHs deposition, but even nonleafy vegetables are also affected but in less proportion. The potato, radish, and carrots (root vegetables) uptake PAHs greatly from the soil due to its higher penetrating capacity. Similarly stem vegetables like tomato, egg plant and cucumber are also affected easily (Bansal and Kim, 2015 the range of 1.9-6.0 and 4.1-15 μg/kg in strawberries and apples (Wennrich et al., 2002).

PAHs contaminate food materials mainly fats and oil-based are possible while oil extraction by solvent, seed drying process, soil burn, the residue of mineral oils, packaging material, contaminated water or soil relocation and raw material of vegetable oil (Amzad Hossain and Salehuddin, 2012). Moret et al. (2005) reported 2000 μg/kg of total PAHs in crude oil and 6.40-76.08 μg L − 1 in corn oil (Dost and Deli, 2012).

Chocolate is one of the favourite food of all ages all over the world and it is a key ingredient for candies, bars, milkshakes, cookies but the main ingredient of chocolate is cocoa (Bansal and Kim, 2015). Globally 2.83 million tons of cocoa consumption was found between 1990 and 2000. Similarly, in Germany, 9.1 kg per capita chocolate consumption was found in 2007, and these chocolates were found to be contaminated by PAHs during cocoa seeds drying, roasting, fermenting, blending and winnowing (Bansal and Kim, 2015). Ziegenhals et al. (2009) (Kumari et al., 2012).

On the other hand, meat is a major protein source by humans used all over the world, but it is readily prone to be contaminated by PAHs. The meat products are usually contaminated by PAHs with the traditional meat preservation techniques using smoking by organic matter combustion. The grilling (or barbequed) meat process contributes about 21% of daily Benzo[a]pyrenehuman intake in the USA (Kazerouni et al., 2001). Farhadian et al. (2010) reported Benzo[a]pyrene concentration of 12.5 μg/kg in beef products like beef satay, chicken satay and grilled chicken. International agency for cancer research has pointed Benzo[a] pyrene as a possible human carcinogen (Agarwal et al., 2009).

Seafood is mostly preferred as a consumer's tasty, cheap meats with essential fatty acids. Still, they are one of the largely affected meats by PAHs because fishes (chub mackerel sardine, horse mackerel, mandarin fish, etc.) while preserved by smoking and the cooking style like fried cooking and grilling (Bansal and Kim, 2015). Not only fishes but many other kinds of seafoods like shrimp, scallop, oyster, mussels and crab are also contaminated by PAHs. PAHs like Fluoranthene, Phenanthrene, Anthracene is present in more than 50% of robust tongue fish, mandarin fish and in Japanese Spanish mackerel (Zhang et al., 2010). Smoked Korean fish had Benzo[a]pyrene at a range of 0.17-2.87 μg/kg (Cho and Shin, 2012). The genotoxins concentration was observed (5 and 2.27 μg/kg) in chrysene and Benzo[a]anthracene (Alomirah et al., 2011).

Beverages are consumed for instant energy by the people of all age group. Several industries apply recent methods for the production of liquid products like milkshakes, fresh fruit juices and instant coffee. These products contain a higher amount of PAHs and are absolute threats to human society (Bansal and Kim, 2015). Milk is the key ingredient of dairy products which has been undergone with various treatment techniques like heat treatment and processing based on the products being produced. According to Naccari et al. (2011), PAHs were observed in many types of milk samples like whole milk, semi-skimmed milk, ultrahigh treated and pasteurized milk. Apart from milk and juices, a large population of people found to consume alcoholic beverages which are contaminated by PAHs under raw material and storage containers. Sugarcane juices (around 50%) are found to contain PAHs due to the utilization of waste crops by the farmers after sugar cane harvest to evaporate water to get a higher concentration of sugar (Bansal and Kim, 2015). The PAHs contamination in coffee happened during the roasting process (flame toasting, toasting by gas, coal grilling, and electric oven toasting) at the temperature of 220-250 • C. The coffee brew samples were reported with 0.52 and 1.8 μg L − 1 of Benzo[a]pyrene, the other PAHs such as Phenanthrene, Fluoranthene, Fluorene, Benzo[k]fluoranthene were also found in coffee brewed samples (Bansal and Kim, 2015). The prime factors of PAHs from both plant and animal-based sources have been represented in Fig. 4.

div.head: PAHs in soil
div.p: Soil is readily contaminated with PAHs by the processes like aluminium and coal production, wood preservation, petrochemical processes, cement manufacturing, rubber tyre manufacturing, waste incineration, bush fires, contaminated water irrigation, traffic emissions, asphalt constituents and power plant treatments (Banger et al., 2010;Alegbeleye et al., 2017). According to Marquès et al. (2017), in Norway at an abandoned mining town, Pyramiden total PAHs concentration of 52 ng/g dry wt was recorded in the unimpacted sites and 186-11600 ng/g dry wt was observed in impacted areas. Wilcke (2007) reported 20 different PAHs in 12 geographic region samples (225 topsoil samples) at a concentration range of 4.8-186,000 μg kg − 1 . A total PAHs concentration range of 65 ng/g to 12,000 ng/g was observed in Korea (25 sites at Ulsan) in 2010 (Kwon and Choi, 2014). The major four soil PAHs contaminating processes were identified to be diesel combustion (54%), coke oven (23%), gasoline and heavy oil combustion (14%) and coal/biomass burning (9%). According to Wang et al. (2008), soil PAHs concentration close to the road is 7189 μg/kg and away from the roads (10 m) is 2404 μg/kg in New Orleans (Wang et al., 2008).

The hydrophobic PAHs are usually present in nonaqueous phases which are then adsorbed to the soil, organic matter, particles, crystals or solids and oily phase (Peng et al., 2008). The level of different PAHs presence in various countries at different periods is given in Table 2.

div.head: Environment persistence and toxicity of PAHs
div.p: In the environment, the PAHs spread from one place to another through air and water, which then easily reaches the marine environment and finally attains human consumption through marine foods. Persistence of PAHs in the environment is possible due to its chemical structure, bioavailability, concentration, dispersion, temperature, pH, levels of oxygen, soil type and nutrient availability for pollutantdegrading microbes. PAHs exhibits deleterious effects to the human health based on the rate of exposure and innate toxicity of different compounds which causes carcinogenicity (ability or tendency to induce cancer), genotoxicity (ability to induce non-transmissible DNA damage), cytotoxicity (the ability of being toxic to cells), nephrotoxicity (damage to the kidney), cardiotoxicity (capacity to cause damage to heart muscles, ocular toxicity (ability to induce eye disorders), haemotoxicity (destruction of red blood cells), neurotoxicity (damage to the brain and nervous system), hepatotoxicity (ability to elicit damage to the liver), immunotoxicity (capacity to repress the immune system), teratogenicity (induction of malformation of embryo or foetus) and mutagenicity (capacity to incite transmissible genetic mutations) towards humans and animals (Ossai et al., 2020).

Department of Health and Human Services, US (DHHS) has analysed various animal carcinogen like benzo(b) fluoranthene, benzo(k)fluoranthene, dibenzo(a,h)anthracene, benzo(a)anthracene, benzo(a)pyrene, indeno(1,2,3-c,d) pyrene and benzo(j)fluoranthene. International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) has identified certain compounds as carcinogens for human-like benzo(a)pyrene, benzo(j)fluoranthene, benzo(a)anthracene, benzo(k)fluoranthene, indeno(1,2,3-c,d)pyrene and benzo(b)fluoranthene (ATSDR, 1995).

div.head: PAHs degradation
div.p: Since the hazardous PAHs pollution is deleterious to environment damage, cleaning of the polluted areas is mandatory so as to restore the environment to a normal state. At present, various physical and chemical methods of PAHs cleaning are available like incineration, skimming and absorbing, base-catalyzed de-chlorination, ultrasonic treatment, dispersing and solidifying, solvent extraction, UV oxidation, fixation, Cyclodextrin (CD) extraction, Tenax or XAD extraction, Supercritical fluid extraction (SFE), Passive sampler methods (PSMs) and Subcritical fluid extraction (Ge et al., 2016;Oh et al., 2016;Rajasekhar et al., 2021). But, these technologies have several downsides like a regulatory burden, cost, complexity and sometimes inefficiency in completely removing the compounds. Such consequences can be easily eliminated by using biological treatment methods which are eco-friendly, efficient in clean-up and above all nutrient providence for living organisms via breaking down of organic or inorganic matters in aerobic and anaerobic process.

Bioremediation (reclamation or biorestoration) is a natural degradation process where the pollutant is either removed or been converted into less harmful compounds by living organisms. Usually, microorganisms play an essential role in converting pollutant into carbon dioxide, water and cell biomass (Langenbach, 2013). The bioremediation process is achieved by various methods such as biosorption (dead/viable microbial biomass), biostimulation (stimulating viable native microbial population), phytoremediation (plants), bioaugmentation (artificial introduction of viable populations), rhizoremediation (plant and microbe interaction) and bioaccumulation (live cells) (Sharma, 2012: Zheng et al., 2021). Algae, fungi, bacteria are very successful in PAHs degradation and several researchers have confirmed more than 100 genera, 200 species including algae (19 genera), fungi (103 genera), cyanobacteria (9 genera) and bacteria (79 genera) isolated from the marine environment to be highly effective PAHs biodegrades (Fingas, 1995;Hara et al., 2003;Bao et al., 2012;Spier et al., 2013;Jiang et al., 2013; Prince et al., 2013; Brakstad et al., 2014).
BaA, BkF, BaP, IP, DBA, BPE a Italy Indoor-2014 1.8-8.4 ng/m 3 Romagnoli et al.,

div.head: PAHs degradation by algae
div.p: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic algae (cyanobacteria (blue-green); diatoms (red and brown) and green algae)) which are abundant in the aquatic environments exhibits a vital role in PAHs degradation. Narro et al. (1992aNarro et al. ( ,1992b found that cyanobacteria metabolize naphthalene and phenanthrene. Similarly, another study of Warshawsky et al. (1988) demonstrated freshwater green alga (Selenastrum capricornutum) mediated conversion of BaP to cis-dihydrodiols by dioxygenase enzyme action. Borde et al. (2003) reported the combination of algal-bacterial (Ralstonia basilensis, Acinetobacter haemolyticus, Pseudomonas migulae, Sphingomonas yanoikuyae and Chlorella sorokiniana) microcosms based PAHs degradation by one-stage treatment where the algal photosynthesis improved the PAHs degradation. In a study by Lei et al. (2007) different microalgal species (Scenedesmus platydiscus, Selenastrum capricornutum, Scenedesmus quadricauda and Chlorella vulgaris) were used for the PAHs (fluoranthene, pyrene and both fluoranthene and pyrene) degradation, among which C. vulgaris, S. capricornutum showed 78% and 48% of PAHs removal efficacy in 7 days respectively.

Mostly, the degradation of mixed PAHs (fluoranthene and pyrene) was found to be higher when compared to the single compounds. Another study by Chan et al., (2006) reported the use of S. capricornutum for degrading mixture of PAHs (fluoranthene, phenanthrene and pyrene) into various metabolites like hydroxylated fluoranthene, pyrene, dihydroxy phenanthrene and monohydroxy phenanthrene (Chan et al., 2006). Similarly, Ke et al. (2010) reported S. capricornutum based degradation of four PAHs compounds such as B(a)P, pyrene, fluoranthene and phenanthrene simultaneously (Ke et al., 2010). Immobilized heterotrophic green microalgal strain Prototheca zopfii has also been used to degrade several PAHs compounds (Ueno et al., 2008).

div.head: PAHs degradation by fungi
div.p: The ligninolytic fungal mediated PAHs degradation was intensely studied in the past few years in which the low substrate specificity of ligninolytic fungi enzymes is more appropriate for degradation of different compounds, including PAHs (Cajthaml et al., 2001). Lignin peroxidase (LiP), phenoloxidases (laccases, tyrosinases), manganese dependent peroxidase (MnP) are the three enzymes commonly employed ligninolytic enzymes which are mainly involved in degrading lignin and analogue PAHs. The majority of fungal species are capable of tolerating high concentrations of recalcitrant compounds, including PAHs, under extreme conditions like low pH and high temperature (Silva et al., 2009;Ding et al., 2013). Arun and Eyini (2011) collected and identified 130 wild basidiomycetes fungi (From Thandigudi hill, Western Ghats region, Tamil Nadu, India) and screened their potentiality to degrade various PAHs (naphthalene, acenaphthene, fluorene, anthracene, and pyrene and mixed PAHs). Phellinus spp., and Polyporus sulphureus exhibit excellent degradation ability under both liquid state and solid-state fermentation. Clemente et al. (2001) screened thirteen ligninolytic fungal strains for PAHs degradation and observed 69% naphthalene degradation with MnP activity (strain 984), followed by 17% degradation with LiP and laccase activity (strain 870), finally with 12% Phenanthrene degradation with MnP and laccase activities (strain 870).

Another report by Silva et al. (2009), showed soil fungal based PAHs degradation under low-oxygen conditions. Aspergillus spp., Trichocladium canadense and Fusarium oxysporum extensively degraded low PAHs (2-3 rings) where aspergillus spp., Achremonium spp., T. canadense, Verticillium spp degraded HMW PAHs (4-7 rings) effectively. Studies on PAHs degradation by white-rot fungi are mostly available, few white-rot fungi like Phanerochaete chrysosporium, Pleurotus ostreatus and Bjerkandera adusta have been extensively studied for biodegradation of PAHs (Haritash and Kaushik, 2009). Thulasinathan et al., (2021) analysed the combination of bioelectricity generation from septic tank waste water in anode chamber and PAHs (naphthalene, acenaphthene, fluorene, and anthracene) degradation in cathode chamber via ligninolytic enzymes by using Psathyrella candolleana (Thulasinathan et al., 2021).

div.head: PAHs degradation by bacteria
div.p: In the past thirty years, numerous bioremediation techniques have been examined to remove PAHs contamination from the environment. Compared to algae, fungi and plants, bacteria have exhibited the most favourable and cost-effective methods of PAHs degradation. For more than three billion years, bacteria have been evolved, developed and adopted a mechanism to degrade several environmental pollutants (Ghosal et al., 2016). In bacteria, several metabolic pathways involved in PAHs degradation have also been developed from many researchers (Peng et al., 2008;Seo et al., 2009;Mallick et al., 2011;Govarthanan et al., 2017Govarthanan et al., , 2020. Usually, the bacterial based PAHs degradation strategies are performed under both aerobic and anaerobic mode. In the aerobic mode of PAHs degradation, oxygen acts as the final electron acceptor and also severs as co-substrate for hydroxylation and oxygenolytic ring cleavage of the aromatic rings. In anaerobic PAHs degradation, the bacteria utilize an entirely distinct approach to breakdown the aromatic ring based on reductive reactions (Mallick et al., 2011).

For several decades, the aerobic mode of PAHs degradation is the most widely studied one, but the study regarding anaerobic method is recently gaining attention from the researchers. The anaerobic catabolism mainly happens in submerged soils, aquatic sediments and aquifers in which sulfate or ferric ions and nitrate acts as final electron acceptors of bacteria (Foght, 2008). Additionally, oxygenase-mediated metabolism via monooxygenase or dioxygenase enzymes confirms the aerobic condition to be favourable for PAHs degradation. Hydroxylation of an aromatic ring is the first step of aerobic PAHs degradation via dioxygenase formation of a cis-dihydrodiol and action of dehydrogenase, which gets rearomatized to a diol. Then diol intermediates are cleaved by extra diol or intra diol ring-cleaving dioxygenases via ortho-cleavage or meta-cleavage pathway; finally, catechols formed by the TCA cycle intermediates (Evans et al., 1965;Cerniglia, 1992;Mallick et al., 2011). Several studies have proved the effectivity of bacterial species to utilize PAHs as sole sources of carbon, like Acinetobacter, Aeromonas, Alcanivorax, Arthrobacter, Bacillus, Burkholderia, Cellulomonas, Corynebacterium, Dietzia, Enterobacter, Gordonia, Haemophilus, Marinobacter, Microbulbifer, Micrococcus, Mycobacterium, Paenibacillus, Pseudomonas, Rhodococcus, Sphingomonas, and Xanthomonas. Rather than using monoculture for PAHs biodegradation, employment of fungi and bacteria under co-cultivation technique was proved to be more promising in PAHs bio-deterioration. As per the investigation of Arun et al., (2008), on employing co-cultures of basidiomycetes fungus and Pseudomonas spp., significant results encompassing the importance of co-cultivation was observed. Co-cultivation of Coriolus versicolor with Pseudomonas spp., And Fomitopsis palustris with Pseudomonas spp., were very efficient in degrading pyrene with 93.7% efficiency.

div.head: Role of biosurfactants in PAHs biodegradation
div.p: Numerous microorganisms produce biosurfactants with wide chemical diversity and different molecular structures. The different types of microbial surfactants are polymeric surfactants, glycolipids, particulate biosurfactants, lipopeptides, fatty acids, neutral lipids, and phospholipids (Vater et al., 2002;Abdel-Mawgoud et al., 2010;Zang et al., 2021). Biosurfactants are classified as tail groups and head groups; tail groups adsorb soil particles or hydrophobic contaminants, whereas head groups opt to take lipophilic groups in the aqueous phase (Mao et al., 2015). Bacterial biosurfactants reduce interfacial tension of an interface or surface tension (ST) and make them readily available for the microbes (Patowary et al., 2017).

According to Das et al. (2008), Bacillus circulans produced biosurfactant has emulsified the petrol, diesel, kerosene, hexadecane and benzene whereas biosurfactants produced from Acinetobacter radioresistens emulsified α-naphthol benzene, anthracene, fluoranthene, fluorene, phenanthrene, benzo(a)pyrene, chrysene, hexyl phenylbenzene, perylene, hexyl benzyl cyclosilane, pyrene and 1,10-phenanthroline (Das et al., 2008;Toren et al., 2002). Usually, PAHs degrading surfactants are classified into four groups, such as anionic, non-ionic, cationic, and mixed-type surfactants. The biosurfactant increases the bioavailability and dissipation of PAHs in the PAHs polluted soil.

div.head: Bacterial biofilms mediated PAHs degradation
div.p: The commencement of microbial-based xenobiotic degradation was based on the freely suspended planktonic cells. But in recent years, several studies have revealed that biofilm mediated environmental pollutant degradation is an effective one (Mangwani et al., 2014a(Mangwani et al., , 2014b, 2016b, 2017a,2017b. Microbial cells that produce extracellular polymeric substances make cluster formation for surface adhesion in every moist environment termed as biofilm (Singh et al., 2006). Microbial biofilms can be formed by either single bacterial species or by mixed-species like algae, fungi, bacteria, and protozoa that are mutually joined under abiotic or biotic surfaces (Singh et al., 2006). The sessile biofilm structures mainly act as protective factors from environmental stresses like nutrient unavailability and also acts as a means to communicate and exchange genetic material. The bioremediation of hazardous chemicals through biofilm is getting interesting because of its tolerance towards the toxic compounds. When using planktonic microorganisms mediated degradation, high concentrations of compounds are found to be harmful towards the microbes. However, biofilm mediated degradation possess higher tolerance against environmental changes like pollutants with high concentrations, antibiotics, temperature, pH and salt concentration (Heipieper et al., 1991;Hall-Stoodley et al., 2004).

Exopolysaccharides (EPS) is composed of some major components such as polysaccharides (for Aggregation of bacterial cells, Adhesion, the cohesion of biofilms, retention of water, protective barrier, sink for excess energy and sorption of environmental pollutants), proteins (for Adhesion, the cohesion of biofilms, aggregation of bacterial cells, electron donor or acceptor, enzymatic activity, the export of cell components, sorption of environmental pollutants and sink for excess energy and protective barrier), DNA (for Exchange of genetic information, the cohesion of biofilms, adhesion and aggregation of bacterial cells), surfactants, lipids and water (medium for movements for nutrients, hydrophobicity Provides hydrated environment and Bacterial attachment and detachment) and divalent ions (For the regulation of EPS production, regulation of bap and mechanical stability) (Flemming and Wingender, 2010). Biofilm growth requires four distinctive physiological states like i) Habituation of the substratum by various inorganic and organic molecules produced by microbes thus provides a beneficial place for cell settlement, followed by the interaction of the planktonic cell. ii) Binding of microbial cells to the surface, initially reversible and subsequently irreversible.iii) Multiplication of cells after the irreversible attachment. iv) Secretion of EPS, thus helpful in the binding of cells to each other. The EPS matrix mainly comprises of polysaccharides, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids which are responsible for the mechanical stability of biofilms.

Bioremediation by biofilm is a better alternative for other planktonic microorganisms mediated degradation since biofilm producing microbes has higher adaptation chances towards toxic environmental pollutants and is also safer for the environment. In the early 1980s, studies regarding biofilm mediated degradation were started and are more promising due to its environmental friendliness. Quorum sensing (QS) is an important factor for biofilm mediated PAHs degradation where bacteria communicate cell-cell by signalling molecules called autoinducers (AIs) (Mangwani et al., 2012). The AIs regulate various bacterial features like biofilm formation, sporulation, virulence, bioluminescence and genetic competence (Mangwani et al., 2012). Mangwani et al. (2016aMangwani et al. ( , 2016b reported exogenous N-acyl homoserine lactones improved PAHs biodegradation of phenanthrene and pyrene by using marine bacteria Pseudomonas pseudoalcaligenes NP103 and Pseudomonas aeruginosa N6P6. Various studies also revealed that QS is an important factor for PAHs degradation (Kumari et al., 2016;Mangwani et al., 2015Mangwani et al., , 2017.

Pseudomonas mendocina NR802 with phenanthrene degrading potentiality was isolated from the East Coast of Odisha, India, using a 20 mM Ca 2+ increased biofilm growth and 82.9 ± 4.37% of phenanthrene degradation was observed (Mangwani et al., 2014b). According to Mangwani et al. (2014), biofilm mediated PAHs degradation by employing Stenotrophomonas. Acidaminiphila obtained maximum degradation of phenanthrene (71.1 ± 3.1%) and pyrene (40.2 ± 2.4%). The biofilm mode of degradation was compared with planktonic culture, where planktonic mode yielded less quantity of phenanthrene (38.7 ± 2.5%) and pyrene degradation (29.7 ± 1%). In another study done by Mangwani et al. (2016), examined under different conditions with diverse microbes to obtain increased biofilm growth by using different carbon sources (fructose, xylose, raffinose, arabinose, sucrose, rhamnose and glucose), salt concentration (0-6%), temperature (28 and 37 • C), pH (6-9) by Alcaligenes faecalis NCW-402, Pseudomonas pseudoalcaligenes NP103, Sporosarcina luteola NR402, Paenibacillus lautus NE3B01, Stenotrophomonas acidaminiphila NCW-702, Pseudomonas aeruginosa N6P6, Pseudomonas alcaliphila NE3B02, Pseudomonas mendocina NR802, Pseudomonas sp., NP202 and Lysinibacillus fusiformis NCW903. The study revealed maximum biofilm was attained with glucose as a carbon source, 2% salt concentration, pH 7, 37 • C temperature and maximum phenanthrene degradation 85.5% byP. aeruginosa N6P6 and 78.7% byPseudoalcaligenes NP103. 12% and 6.74% pyrene degradation was observed withPaenibacillus lautus NE3B01 and P. alcaliphila NE3B02, respectively.

Several marine bacteria have found to possess the potentiality to degrade PAHs using biofilm mode. Mangwani et al. (2019) collected marine samples form submerged surfaces at Paradip Port, Chilika Lagoon, Rushikulya Estuary and Bhitarkanika Mangroves of Odisha coast, India. From which, the PAHs degrading bacteria were identified as species belonged to the genera Alcaligenes, Lysinibacillus, Proteobacteria, Paenibacillus, Pseudomonas, Stenotrophomonas and Sporosarcina. These bacteria also have the capability to degrade mixed PAHs like naphthalene, anthracene, toluene, biphenyl, among which 75% of the isolates were able to degrade PAHs by biofilm formation. So, the marine environment possesses different potential microbes for bioremediation of environmental pollutants (Shukla et al., 2014(Shukla et al., , 2019Mohanrasu et al., 2018;Mangwani et al., 2019).

In several studies, besides biofilm-producing, bacteria are considered as potential PAHs degraders. Pseudomonas stutzeri T102 showed 14 ppm (70%) of naphthalene degradation in 12 h (Shimada et al., 2012); Sphingobium sp., and Micrococcus sp showed phenanthrene degradation (Zhang et al., 2011); Phenanthrene (100%) and pyrene (78%) degradation was observed by mixed culture of Pseudomonas and Actinobacteria at 7 days (Isaac et al., 2017); naphthalene degradation was observed while using Pseudomonas putida (Dutta et al., 2018) and individual (Anthracene (74.31%), Acenaphthene (67.28%), Fluorene (62.48%), Naphthalene (57.84%), and mixed PAHs (55.85%) degradation were obtained in Klebsiella pneumonia (Premnath et al., 2021).

div.head: Bioaugmentation
div.p: Bioaugmentation is augmenting with desired microbial isolates instigate into PAHs contaminated environment where local PAHs degrading microbial populations are found insufficient. Bioaugmentation has been suggested to solve the pollution problem in contaminated sites (Elliot et al., 2011: Sun et al., 2012: Wu et al., 2020. The exogenous microorganisms that are introduced into the contaminated sites will increase the rate of PAHs degradation. Sometimes cells are encapsulated with carriers (alginate) (Fernández-Luqueño et al., 2011). This phenomenon has been observed in different bioaugmentation mediated PAHs degradation studies (Trzesicka-Miynarz and Ward, 1996;Madsen and Kristensen, 1997). The Bioaugmentation mediated PAHs degradation are not successful all the time as there are some failure due to the influence of many environmental factors such as both abiotic, biotic stress, temperature fluctuations, high or low pH, excess or lack of water, toxic pollutants, nutrient availability and autochthonous competition between organisms.

div.head: Biostimulation
div.p: The increase of autochthonous biomass in PAHs contaminated environments is done by adding nutrients to promote co-metabolism by the process called Biostimulation. It will increase PAHs dissipation (de Lorenzo, 2008;Scullion, 2006). The addition of nutrients like N, P, K, S, and Cu, autochthonous microorganisms will also pave an efficient way to remove PAHs in nutrient or substrate deficient strikes of the environment (Atagana, 2006;Fernandez-Luqueno et al., 2009). Although the introduction of several substrates like crop residues (Molina-Barahona et al., 2004), sugarcane bagasse pith (Pèrez-Armendáriz et al., 2004), sewage sludge compost (Hamdi et al., 2007), vermicompost (Contreras-Ramos et al., 2008), food waste compost (Joo et al., 2007), corn stalks, compost, corn fermentation byproduct, manure, peat, sawdust (Moorman et al., 2001), wastewater sludge (Fernández-Luqueño et al., 2008;Fernandez-Luqueno et al., 2009), ground rice hulls, dried blood (Straube et al., 2003) have also resulted in a significant increase of PAHs dissipation. The addition of 5% manure in PAHs contaminated environment increased available P, K and hydrolyzable N, which helped the growth of PAHs degrading bacteria (Liu et al., 2010). It will be helpful to employ phytoremediation in PAHs contaminated soil and usually, rhizosphere bacteria have higher degradation capability compared to root-free soil bacteria (Álvarez-Bernal et al., 2007;Binet et al., 2000).

div.head: PAH degradation under other various conditions
div.p: Nitrate-based biodegradation of PAHs is a promising replacement of aerobic (oxygen-based) bioremediation because nitrate is 10,000 times highly soluble compared to oxygen; also, it is cost-effective for PAHs degradation (Rockne and Strand, 2001;Ambrosoli et al., 2005;Shao et al., 2009). There are number of studies available and proved efficient In situ nitrate-based bioremediation in soil, sediment and groundwater (MacRae and Hall, 1998;Mcnally et al., 1998;Dou et al., 2009;Urlbe-Jongbloed and Bishop, 2007) by using pure cultures or enriched cultures with an added advantage of cost-effectiveness.

Several studies have reported PAHs degradation under sulfatereducing conditions (Coates et al., 1996;Zhang and Young, 1997;Lei et al., 2007). In marine sediment, nitrate and oxygen are in minimal quantity, but sulfate is abundant, thus marine sediment PAHs degradation coupled with sulfate reduction is observed. In some cases, both Fe (III) and Mn(II) reduction prevailed mostly in sediments and these ions act as electron acceptors of bacteria (Lu et al., 2011). The pH also plays an important role in mineralization of PAHs under various conditions, the rate of mineralization of naphthalene is highest in nitrate-reducing (301-552 μg/l/day) followed by sulfate-reducing (221-320 μg/l/day) and lowest in Fe(III) (174-292 μg/l/day) conditions (Ramsay et al., 2003).

div.head: PAHs degradation by genetically modified microorganisms
div.p: The unsuccessful and very slow pattern of PAHs bioremediation is resulted because of the heaviness of contamination along with biotic and abiotic factors involved. To overcome the contraindications in PAH degradation, the involvement of GEMs in bioremediation processes are highly commendable and promising, even though very little information is available (Ee et al., 2005;Singh et al., 2008;Megharaj et al., 2011). Employment of genetic engineering approaches are helpful to enhance the degradation activity by using specific enzymes involved PAHdegradation pathways with a broader range of substrate specificity, which thereby up-regulate the mineralization of pollutants found available in the environment (Ee et al., 2005;Singh et al., 2008). Numerous molecular biology tools like gene duplication, gene conversion and gene delivery systems mediated by plasmid or transposon are present recently, thus involve in the essential roles to stimulate the potentiality to biodegrade PAHs using microorganisms occurring naturally (Ee et al., 2005;Singh et al., 2008;Megharaj et al., 2011). But the stability of the GEMs associated with the recombinant plasmids used should be analysed earlier so as to ensure their successive application on the field (Samanta et al., 2002). Above all, the GEMs used in the contaminated environment can transfer to other places and could multiply under favourable environmental conditions. Thus complete understanding about the side effects caused by the GEMs is essential before releasing into the environment, therefore would probable helpful in restricting the application of pollutant in the environment (Samanta et al., 2002;Ee et al., 2005;Singh et al., 2008;Megharaj et al., 2011).

div.head: PAHs degradation by microbial consortia through cometabolism
div.p: Infrequently, it is being observed that the genes responsible for complete mineralization of the organic pollutants such as PAHs are seldom present in few microorganisms. Thus, researchers focused on developing complete degradation of those pollutants using microbial consortium. Among the microbial consortium, each and every microbe possesses specific roles in every step of degradation, where the intermediate products produced by certain microbes are consumed by other microbes of the consortium. In contrast, calcitrant compounds can be degraded by the phenomenon of co-metabolism in the presence of few degradable compounds. A few microorganisms can degrade PAHs through the very complex phenomenon of co-metabolism. Above all, the PAHs present in the environment as the mixture, thus the bioremediation of contaminated sites could be crucially done by co-metabolism. The co-metabolism of the PAHs shows synergistic effects on the biodegradation other PAHs, especially high molecular weight PAHs (Van Herwijnen et al., 2003). In an investigation, as Rhodococcus spp., strain S1 were grown using anthracene involve in cometabolism and convert phenanthrene to phenanthrene trans-9,10-dihydrodiol (Tongpim and Pickard, 1999). The Sphingomonas spp., LB126 grown under fluorine was found to involve in the cometabolic degradation of phenanthrene, fluoranthene, anthracene and dibenzothiophene (Van Herwijnen et al., 2003). Similarly, co-metabolism of creosote-PAHs mixtures (pyrene, fluoranthene, phenanthrene) was observed on the pyrene degrading strain of Mycobacterium sp. AP1 (López et al., 2008). The degradation rate of the every PAHs is associated with its aqueous solubility, whereas, the rate of biodegradation of pyrene and fluoranthene are considerably lower while compared to phenanthrene (López et al., 2008). Similarly, in a different study using succinate grown Beijerinckia spp., and its respective mutant strain Beijerinckia spp., strain B8/36 co-metabolic biodegradation of acenaphthene and acenaphthylene has also been reported (Schocken and Gibson, 1984). The acenaphthene has been found to be co-metabolize and converted to 1-acenaphthene, 1-acenaphthenol, acenaphthene quinone, 1,2-acenaphthene diol and 1,2-dihydroxy acenaphthylene by both the strains (wild and mutant). In contrast, co-metabolic activity was observed on phenanthrene biodegradation by the Sphingobium spp., strain PNB which proved to co-metabolize the compounds like pyrene, benzo[a]pyrene, benzo[a]anthracene, acenaphthene, fluoranthene (Roy, 2013).

While considering the biodegradation of PAHs by white-rot fungi, it is found very promising by increasing the target compound bioavailability when provided with the bacterial consortium. Usually, the probable enzymes needed to completely metabolize HMWPAHs are lacking; thus the fungi could transform the compounds to respective polar metabolites using the enzymes synthesised extracellularly which are further metabolized by bacteria and other microbes (Sutherland, 1992). Thus it was evidently observed that HMWPAHs such as benzo [a] anthracene, dibenzo [a,h]anthracene and chrysene could be significantly degraded by inoculating fungal and bacterial co-cultures into the PAH contaminated soil (Boonchan et al., 2000).

Subsequently, the degradation of PAH present in nature has happened through a set of coordination events reconciled by bacteria and fungi consortium, where the primary step of oxidation was carried out by the fungi (Boonchan et al., 2000;Cerniglia and Sutherland, 2010). Other than fungi and bacteria consortium numerous strains of microalgae in the consortium are also found to involve in PAHs degradation. And these microalgae are regarded as a most potential candidate of PAHs degradation in the aquatic environment exclusively.

In some cases, metabolic competition is also a significant feature of biodegradation, while two separate biodegradable PAHs are combined in a medium (Bouchez et al., 1995). As low molecular weight PAHs like fluorene and phenanthrene are existing the same medium, the degradation activity of pyrene and fluoranthene could be inhibited (Dean--Ross et al., 2002). However, generation of dead-end products during co-metabolism of the non-growth substrates are also the reason for inhibition of PAHs biodegradation (Stringfellow and Aitken, 1995).

div.head: Conclusions and future perspective
div.p: The elimination of persistent environmental pollutants is the biggest problem worldwide, where PAHs are one of the significant environmental pollutants mainly due to its hydrophobicity. The toxicity of PAHs pollution in humans, as well as to the environment, has thoroughly investigated. Bioremediation is a promising tool for the degradation of PAHs. Several studies showed promising techniques both in physical and chemical mediated degradation. In recent years numerous microorganisms with enzyme-based biochemical pathways with unique catabolic efficiency have been reported. The microbes like algae, bacteria and fungi degrade or remove PAHs from contaminated environments in an eco-friendly approach. They utilize very fewer amounts of time and energy to transform PAH into non-hazardous or less hazardous forms. Bioremediation of PAHs mainly relies on several environmental factors like pH, temperature, nutrient supply and nature of compounds. Usually, bacterial PAHs degradation is done with the use or involvement of biosurfactants, bioaugmentation, biostimulation, and biofilm formation. In contrast, algae degrade PAHs by biosorption and enzymemediated degradation, but fungal based PAHs degradation is mainly done by the action of its ligninolytic enzymes. However, microorganism mediated PAHs degradation is essential for a deeper understanding of metabolic pathways, genetic regulation, and construction that require potential PAHs degrading strains.

Bioremediation of PAHs by microorganisms is an efficient and greener technology, but still not fully exploit due to several factors like inaccurate risk assessment policies and efficient tolls not available to monitor the biodegradation processes. The PAHs degradation efficiency has increased by managing the key issues such as microbial tolerance to different compounds, substrate specificity, catabolic genes expression, encoded enzyme kinetics and the stability. In recent years, various methods have been in developmental stages for enhanced bioremediation such as electrokinetic remediation, biocatalyst-assisted remediation, vermiremediation, transgenic approaches, biosurfactant flushing and nanoremediation. In the near future, these types of approaches may become vital for enhancing microorganisms or enzymes responsible for higher PAHs bioremediation in the environment.
